reasoning: The critique targets a specific sub-argument in §3.3: that on bounded, separately-aggregating views, extremely tiny fractions of “bads” (e.g., 1 part in 10^22) prevent a mostly-great future. This is one route by which the essay argues most plausible value functions are fussy, but it is not the only route (e.g., the unbounded/approximately-linear argument, fat-tailed value-efficiency, and earlier ‘fragility’ considerations). So even if the critique landed, it would only partially weaken the overall “no easy eutopia” case (moderate centrality). Substantively, the critique correctly flags that the dramatic numerical conclusion depends on modeling choices: mapping “fraction of resources” to “amount of bad,” assuming linear scaling of disvalue with spatial extent, and treating bads as a fungible mass-term rather than intensity×duration (integrated suffering) with possible containment/mitigation dynamics. However, it doesn’t fully engage the strongest version of Forethought’s point: that in very large futures, even extremely low per-resource rates of bads can yield enormous absolute bads under many aggregators, and that separate aggregation is meant to capture exactly that sensitivity. The critique therefore weakens the illustrative ‘tiny fraction’ claim more than it refutes the underlying sensitivity argument (moderate strength). Relevance is mid-to-high because it speaks to a key Tier-2 pillar of the Better Futures program (fussiness/narrow-target arguments) and highlights an internal modeling hinge (aggregation and scaling) that could change quantitative implications, though it doesn’t directly engage Forethought’s most live Tier-3 governance strategy questions.
title: "The 'tiny fraction of bads ruins everything' claim is model-dependent"
